title: Freddie Mercury had 'wider sexual tastes' but 'couldn't fall in love with a man'
text:

Freddie Mercury was not shy when it came to taking lovers but he has admitted the one thing he found it difficult to do.

The late Queen frontman became more hedonistic as he grew older and admitted that he 'could have sex with many people'.

In his later years, his lovers became predominately male but he said there was a different connection with them and that he would 'never be able to fall in love' with another man.

In a new autobiography about the legendary singer, Freddie Mercury: A Life, In His Own Words, the great showman said he would never divulge the explicit details of his relationships.

(Image: Redferns)

(Image: Getty Images)

Freddie said: "It would destroy all the mystery if I always explained everything about myself. To actually come out with it and go into huge detail about all those things, to be honest, is a bit beneath me.

"I have maybe a wider sexual taste than most people, but that’s as far as I’m going to go."

What becomes clear in the autobiography is that sex is a subject that Freddie has spoken about a lot and is something that is dominant in his life.

(Image: ullstein bild via Getty Images)

When it came to falling in love though, this was a different story and he admitted: "I couldn’t fall in love with a man the way I could with a girl."

When it came to loving a woman, the most dominant force in his life was Mary Austin.

Freddie explained: "Our love affair ended in tears, but a deep bond grew out of it, and that’s something nobody can take away from us.

(Image: Getty Images)

"It’s unreachable. People always ask me about sexuality and all those things, right from the early days, but I couldn’t fall in love with a man the same way as I have with Mary.

"All my lovers asked me why they couldn’t replace Mary, but it’s simply impossible."

description: The Queen singer once said that he could 'have sex with many' but he 'couldn't fall in love with them'
